Yes, the conflict between science and religion during the Renaissance period had significant long-term effects on society and culture. The Renaissance marked the beginning of a shift towards a more empirical and rational approach to knowledge, and this shift continued to develop in the centuries that followed.

This shift towards scientific thinking ultimately led to advances in fields such as medicine, technology, and engineering, which significantly improved the quality of life for people around the world. It also enabled the development of new philosophical and ethical systems, such as the ideas of the Enlightenment.

On the other hand, the tension between science and religion also contributed to the development of cultural and social conflicts that continue to this day. For example, debates over topics such as evolution, climate change, and medical technologies have often been framed as conflicts between scientific and religious worldviews.

Overall, the conflict between science and religion during the Renaissance period had complex and long-lasting effects on society and culture, shaping the way we approach knowledge, religion, and the relationship between the two.
